page.title: 06Bisbrooke Village
page.content:
The name of this village was "Bitel's Brook" in the original Domesday Survey, and this must refer to the streams north and south of the village which drain into the Welland. There are about thirty houses in the village, mostly made of local limestone. There are few amenities, and the camping and caravan site marked on most O.S.Maps is no longer operating.
The inn, known as "The Gate Inn" was originally built as a farmhouse, but probably developed into an inn when the railway came to the area. Some say it used to be called "The Ragged Urchin". The name was changed to a more desireable one, which refers to the kissing gates on "Inhams", the old right of way to Uppingham.
